title: A Guide to the Universe of Milks
text:
Pediatricians generally recommend that 1-year-olds drink whole milk, “to provide energy and fat that little people need for growing bodies and growing brains,” said Dr. Jonathon Maguire, M.D., a pediatrician and researcher at St. Michael’s Hospital in Toronto. And that those ages 2 and up switch to 1-percent or non-fat (skim) to decrease their saturated fat intake.

But the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute guidelines say that if your baby is growing well and is consuming enough healthy fats, he can move straight to a reduced-fat milk at age 1; and that all kids aged 2 and up should drink skim milk. While the A.A.P.’s general guidelines are not this strict, they agree that this approach can be appropriate for kids with a family history of — or other risk factors for — obesity or heart disease.

However, there’s much debate in the scientific community over whether lower-fat milks are really the best options for young children, said Dr. Maguire. Several observational studies published in the past decade, for example, have found that 2- to 4-year-olds who drank whole milk tended to be leaner – not heavier – than those who drank lower-fat milk. And in 2016, Dr. Maguire’s research group published a study which found that 1- to 6-year-olds who drank whole milk not only had lower body mass indices than those who drank lower-fat milk, but also had higher vitamin D levels — perhaps because vitamin D is better-absorbed when it’s consumed with fat.

As with many nutrition studies, it’s not clear why this is or whether the whole milk itself directly led to these benefits. But until we have more conclusive data, this is a choice without a clear answer, said Dr. Maguire, so it’s worth discussing with your pediatrician and considering the big picture of your child’s growth and diet.
description: Whole or reduced-fat milk? Cow’s milk or plant-based milk? The options can be paralyzing when you need to feed your toddler. We’re here to help.
